Chapter 21.21:1: Give the Israelites the following laws:

Chapter 21.21:2: If you buy a Hebrew slave, he shall serve you for six years. In the seventh year he is to be set free without having to pay anything.

Chapter 21.21:4: If his master gave him a wife and she bore him sons or daughters, the woman and her children belong to the master, and the man is to leave by himself.

Chapter 21.21:5: But if the slave declares that he loves his master, his wife, and his children and does not want to be set free,

Chapter 21.21:6: then his master shall take him to the place of worship. There he is to make him stand against the door or the doorpost and put a hole through his ear. Then he will be his slave for life.

Chapter 21.21:7: If a man sells his daughter as a slave, she is not to be set free, as male slaves are.

Chapter 21.21:8: If she is sold to someone who intends to make her his wife, but he doesn't like her, then she is to be sold back to her father; her master cannot sell her to foreigners, because he has treated her unfairly.

Chapter 21.21:9: If a man buys a female slave to give to his son, he is to treat her like a daughter.

Chapter 21.21:10: If a man takes a second wife, he must continue to give his first wife the same amount of food and clothing and the same rights that she had before.

Chapter 21.21:11: If he does not fulfill these duties to her, he must set her free and not receive any payment.

Chapter 21.21:12: Whoever hits someone and kills him is to be put to death.

Chapter 21.21:13: But if it was an accident and he did not mean to kill him, he can escape to a place which I will choose for you, and there he will be safe.

Chapter 21.21:14: But when someone gets angry and deliberately kills someone else, he is to be put to death, even if he has run to my altar for safety.

Chapter 21.21:15: Whoever hits his father or his mother is to be put to death.

Chapter 21.21:16: Whoever kidnaps someone, either to sell him or to keep him as a slave, is to be put to death.

Chapter 21.21:17: Whoever curses his father or his mother is to be put to death.

Chapter 21.21:19: 18-If there is a fight and someone hits someone else with a stone or with his fist, but does not kill him, he is not to be punished. If the one who was hit has to stay in bed, but later is able to get up and walk outside with the help of a cane, the one who hit him is to pay for his lost time and take care of him until he gets well.

Chapter 21.21:20: If a slave owner takes a stick and beats his slave, whether male or female, and the slave dies on the spot, the owner is to be punished.

Chapter 21.21:21: But if the slave does not die for a day or two, the master is not to be punished. The loss of his property is punishment enough.

Chapter 21.21:22: If some men are fighting and hurt a pregnant woman so that she loses her child, but she is not injured in any other way, the one who hurt her is to be fined whatever amount the woman's husband demands, subject to the approval of the judges.

Chapter 21.21:23: But if the woman herself is injured, the punishment shall be life for life,

Chapter 21.21:24: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,

Chapter 21.21:25: burn for burn, wound for wound, bruise for bruise.

Chapter 21.21:26: If someone hits his male or female slave in the eye and puts it out, he is to free the slave as payment for the eye.

Chapter 21.21:27: If he knocks out a tooth, he is to free the slave as payment for the tooth.

Chapter 21.21:28: If a bull gores someone to death, it is to be stoned, and its flesh shall not be eaten; but its owner is not to be punished.

Chapter 21.21:29: But if the bull had been in the habit of attacking people and its owner had been warned, but did not keep it penned up—then if it gores someone to death, it is to be stoned, and its owner is to be put to death also.

Chapter 21.21:30: However, if the owner is allowed to pay a fine to save his life, he must pay the full amount required.

Chapter 21.21:31: If the bull kills a boy or a girl, the same rule applies.

Chapter 21.21:32: If the bull kills a male or female slave, its owner shall pay the owner of the slave thirty pieces of silver, and the bull shall be stoned to death.

Chapter 21.21:33: If someone takes the cover off a pit or if he digs one and does not cover it, and a bull or a donkey falls into it,

Chapter 22.22:1: If someone steals a cow or a sheep and kills it or sells it, he must pay five cows for one cow and four sheep for one sheep.

Chapter 22.22:4: 2-He must pay for what he stole. If he owns nothing, he shall be sold as a slave to pay for what he has stolen. If the stolen animal, whether a cow, a donkey, or a sheep, is found alive in his possession, he shall pay two for one. If a thief is caught breaking into a house at night and is killed, the one who killed him is not guilty of murder. But if it happens during the day, he is guilty of murder.

Chapter 22.22:5: If someone lets his animals graze in a field or a vineyard and they stray away and eat up the crops growing in someone else's field, he must make good the loss with the crops from his own fields or vineyards.

Chapter 22.22:7: If anyone agrees to keep someone else's money or other valuables for him and they are stolen from his house, the thief, if found, shall repay double.

Chapter 22.22:8: But if the thief is not found, the one who was keeping the valuables is to be brought to the place of worship and there he must take an oath that he has not stolen the other one's property.

Chapter 22.22:9: In every case of a dispute about property, whether it involves cattle, donkeys, sheep, clothing, or any other lost object, the two people claiming the property shall be taken to the place of worship. The one whom God declares to be guilty shall pay double to the other one.

Chapter 22.22:12: but if the animal was stolen, the man must repay the owner.

Chapter 22.22:13: If it was killed by wild animals, the man is to bring the remains as evidence; he need not pay for what has been killed by wild animals.

Chapter 22.22:14: If anyone borrows an animal from someone else and it is injured or dies when its owner is not present, he must pay for it.

Chapter 22.22:15: But if that happens when the owner is present, he need not repay. If it is a rented animal, the loss is covered by the rental price.

Chapter 22.22:16: If a man seduces a virgin who is not engaged, he must pay the bride price for her and marry her.

Chapter 22.22:17: But if her father refuses to let him marry her, he must pay the father a sum of money equal to the bride price for a virgin.

Chapter 22.22:18: Put to death any woman who practices magic.

Chapter 22.22:19: Put to death any man who has sexual relations with an animal.

Chapter 22.22:20: Condemn to death anyone who offers sacrifices to any god except to me, the Lord.

Chapter 22.22:21: Do not mistreat or oppress a foreigner; remember that you were foreigners in Egypt.

Chapter 22.22:22: Do not mistreat any widow or orphan.

Chapter 22.22:23: If you do, I, the Lord, will answer them when they cry out to me for help,

Chapter 22.22:28: Do not speak evil of God, and do not curse a leader of your people.

Chapter 22.22:29: Give me the offerings from your grain, your wine, and your olive oil when they are due. Give me your first-born sons.

Chapter 22.22:30: Give me the first-born of your cattle and your sheep. Let the first-born male stay with its mother for seven days, and on the eighth day offer it to me.

Chapter 22.22:31: You are my people, so you must not eat the meat of any animal that has been killed by wild animals; instead, give it to the dogs.

Chapter 23.23:1: Do not spread false rumors, and do not help a guilty person by giving false testimony.

Chapter 23.23:2: Do not follow the majority when they do wrong or when they give testimony that perverts justice.

Chapter 23.23:3: Do not show partiality to a poor person at his trial.

Chapter 23.23:4: If you happen to see your enemy's cow or donkey running loose, take it back to him.

Chapter 23.23:5: If his donkey has fallen under its load, help him get the donkey to its feet again; don't just walk off.

Chapter 23.23:6: Do not deny justice to a poor person when he appears in court.

Chapter 23.23:7: Do not make false accusations, and do not put an innocent person to death, for I will condemn anyone who does such an evil thing.

Chapter 23.23:8: Do not accept a bribe, for a bribe makes people blind to what is right and ruins the cause of those who are innocent.

Chapter 23.23:9: Do not mistreat a foreigner; you know how it feels to be a foreigner, because you were foreigners in Egypt.

Chapter 23.23:10: For six years plant your land and gather in what it produces.

Chapter 23.23:11: But in the seventh year let it rest, and do not harvest anything that grows on it. The poor may eat what grows there, and the wild animals can have what is left. Do the same with your vineyards and your olive trees.

Chapter 23.23:12: Work six days a week, but do no work on the seventh day, so that your slaves and the foreigners who work for you and even your animals can rest.

Chapter 23.23:13: Listen to everything that I, the Lord, have said to you. Do not pray to other gods; do not even mention their names.

Chapter 23.23:14: Celebrate three festivals a year to honor me.

Chapter 23.23:15: In the month of Abib, the month in which you left Egypt, celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread in the way that I commanded you. Do not eat any bread made with yeast during the seven days of this festival. Never come to worship me without bringing an offering.

Chapter 23.23:16: Celebrate the Harvest Festival when you begin to harvest your crops. Celebrate the Festival of Shelters in the autumn, when you gather the fruit from your vineyards and orchards.

Chapter 23.23:17: Every year at these three festivals all your men must come to worship me, the Lord your God.

Chapter 23.23:18: Do not offer bread made with yeast when you sacrifice an animal to me. The fat of animals sacrificed to me during these festivals is not to be left until the following morning.

Chapter 23.23:19: Each year bring to the house of the Lord your God the first grain that you harvest. Do not cook a young sheep or goat in its mother's milk.

Chapter 23.23:20: I will send an angel ahead of you to protect you as you travel and to bring you to the place which I have prepared.

Chapter 23.23:21: Pay attention to him and obey him. Do not rebel against him, for I have sent him, and he will not pardon such rebellion.

Chapter 23.23:22: But if you obey him and do everything I command, I will fight against all your enemies.

Chapter 23.23:23: My angel will go ahead of you and take you into the land of the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, and I will destroy them.

Chapter 23.23:24: Do not bow down to their gods or worship them, and do not adopt their religious practices. Destroy their gods and break down their sacred stone pillars.

Chapter 23.23:25: If you worship me, the Lord your God, I will bless you with food and water and take away all your sicknesses.

Chapter 23.23:26: In your land no woman will have a miscarriage or be without children. I will give you long lives.

Chapter 23.23:27: I will make the people who oppose you afraid of me; I will bring confusion among the people against whom you fight, and I will make all your enemies turn and run from you.

Chapter 23.23:28: I will throw your enemies into panic; I will drive out the Hivites, the Canaanites, and the Hittites as you advance.

Chapter 23.23:29: I will not drive them out within a year's time; if I did, the land would become deserted, and the wild animals would be too many for you.

Chapter 23.23:30: Instead, I will drive them out little by little, until there are enough of you to take possession of the land.

Chapter 23.23:31: I will make the borders of your land extend from the Gulf of Aqaba to the Mediterranean Sea and from the desert to the Euphrates River. I will give you power over the inhabitants of the land, and you will drive them out as you advance.

Chapter 23.23:32: Do not make any agreement with them or with their gods.

Chapter 23.23:33: Do not let those people live in your country; if you do, they will make you sin against me. If you worship their gods, it will be a fatal trap for you.

Chapter 29.29:1: This is what you are to do to Aaron and his sons to dedicate them as priests in my service. Take one young bull and two rams without any defects.
